item.dc:creator: filmil
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1385 (Absolute blog URI not always the best solution) created
item.dc:creator: filmil
item.description:
WP 1.5.1 config requires the administrator to set the absolute blog URI that is used to form all the links on the blog.

This static naming scheme breaks if one needs to access the blog machine using different addresses.

Here is a scenario.

I have a machine at home which is on 24-7, hosting the blog, and have a laptop that I carry to and fro for work. When on the home net with the laptop, I must use name1 to access the machine hosting the blog. Naturally, whoever wishes to look at the blog from the outside world must use its name resolved by a dynamic DNS service.

This means the blog must work when accessed from two different addresses. As WP requires a single static URI for the blog, the above access schema cannot work.

Several popular RSS aggregators (Sage for example) currently don't handle 304's correctly. Instead, they report a URL error and toss out the previously gathered content. I've filed a like bug with that team, but since I have plenty of bandwidth to burn, I've made the 304 report optional:

wp-blog-header.php Line:136 if (!DISPLAY_OLD_CONTENT) { -- jrc if ( ($client_last_modified && $client_etag) ? ... header('HTTP/1.x 304 Not Modified'); exit; } } } Line: 152 --jrc }

DISPLAY_OLD_CONTENT is defined in wp-config.php so I can re-enable it in the future.

item.title: Ticket #1329 (Support for summer time / DST) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description:
Read my comments in this thread:

​http://wordpress.org/support/topic/29648

"Automatic DST changing will likely never be in the WP core because getting it to work reliably across different servers and locales is a colossal chore. You simply can't rely on servers having a reliable and comprehensive TZ database, assuming they have one at all. Bundling a TZ database with WP is not an option because full TZ databases are many times the size of WP. Further, they require constant updating because DST rules are subject to the whims of government."

This is not trivial. If you think it is, try to implement it in a way that works for all locales and all platforms. The one way that will work consistently is to have the user define their transitions to and from DST -- in essence defining their own zone description ( Ex: ​http://www.w3.org/2002/12/cal/tzd/America/Chicago ). That's rather unfriendly though.

The clocks in your house adjust for DST? That's not typical. Those that accomplish this are usually sold into a specific market and have a targeted TZ database and a targeted operating environment. Or, they slave off of the NIST radio signal or the equivalent. WP does not have any of these luxuries.

edited on: 05-17-05 19:08

item.dc:creator: netspy
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1378 (Bug with Conditional GET in wp-blog-header.php not resolved) created
item.dc:creator: netspy
item.description:
The patch for bug #1356 is IMO not correct. A conditional GET request with IF_NONE_MATCH will produce an PHP warning:

PHP Warning: strtotime() [<a href='function.strtotime'>function.strtotime</a>]: Called with an empty time parameter. in /.../wp-blog-header.php on line 139

Here my version of the patch:

if (($client_last_modified && (strtotime($client_last_modified) >= strtotime($wp_last_modified)))

($client_etag && ($client_etag == $wp_etag))) {

if ( preg_match('/cgi/',php_sapi_name()) ) {

header('Status: 304 Not Modified'); echo "\r\n\r\n"; exit;

} else {

if ( version_compare(phpversion(), '4.3.0', '>=') )

header('Not Modified', TRUE, 304);

else

header('HTTP/1.x 304 Not Modified');

exit;

}

}

This works fine with IF_MODIFIED_SINCE and IF_NONE_MATCH requests.
